title: A 37-year low: Warner’s horror tour
text:
Chirp up: Wade v Jadeja 1:34 37-year low: David Warner’s horror tour with the bat 23 minutes ago by Jacob Kuriype Source: FOX SPORTS IT’S been 37 years since an Australian opener has had a tour of India this bad. 
David Warner’s horror campaign with the bat came to an end after lunch on Monday, with the opener caught behind for six after a painful five-ball stay at the crease in which he had worn a short ball on the shoulder and been dropped in the slips. 
The dismissal left him with a series average of 24.12, with just one half-century in eight innings. He should have been out for a golden duck too in that innings. 
That’s the second-worst series average by an Australian opener in India ever (minimum four innings), behind Rick Darling’s 1979 campaign. David Warner fell for six in Australia’s second innings. Source: AP 
Darling averaged 9.25 that series – though it should be said he only batted four times – and was never selected again. 
This is not the first time Warner has struggled in India. In 2013 he averaged 24.57 across seven innings at the top of the order as Australia sunk to a 4-0 series loss. That stands as the third worst series average by an Australian opener in India, just behind this year’s tour. 
But it’s not just India where Warner has struggled. 
LION AT HOME, LAMB ABROAD 
The punchy left-hander averages a remarkable 59.21 in home Tests. That number climbs up to 60.11 across his 58 innings at the top of the order in Australia. That’s the third best average of any opener who has ever played at least 10 home Tests and the best of any Australian. 
The numbers away from home aren’t so flash, however. Outside Australia he only averages 36.61, and the only other countries he averages above 40 are the United Arab Emirates (37.06) and South Africa (90.50). In four countries he averages less than 30 – India (24.25), New Zealand (13.00), Sri Lanka (27.16) and the West Indies (26.90). 
He’s now had seven series in which he has averaged less than 30, and all of them have been away from home. Lyon's takes another five 1:02 
And while Warner has scored the ninth most Test centuries (14) in Australia in history, he has only reached triple figures four times overseas and not once since 2014. 
At 30 years old, Warner has time to turn this record around but we’ve gone well beyond the stage where the disparity between his numbers at home and away cannot be considered a coincidence.
